WRITING.TITLE: [TOMT] [MOVIE] Horror/Scifi movie from pre-1984
WRITING.TEXT: I'm trying to figure out a movie I saw a few times as a kid, hopefully someone here might be able to figure it out. It probably is from pre-1984. It was a low(er) budget scifi movie that (as far as I can remember) was about a space-prisoner transport ship that crashes outside some average rural American community in the fall/winter, and there were three monster aliens that escaped and started killing off the townspeople. The alien cop takes the form of a human and hunts the three aliens with the help of a human woman (she doesn't know he's an alien). She was probably a reporter or a cop. Each monster he kills, he uses something from that to kill the next one. I remember one had lobster claws, and he took the poison from that one to kill the next one, etc. The end of the movie, the aliens human disguise is gone, and he's in the shadows and asks the woman not to approach him, but she does anyway, and sees he's a creepy looking creature with bulging orange eyes. Then a cop blasts him with a shotgun. The end. Anyone have any ideas? This movie creeped me out as a kid, and I'd love to find it again and see how bad it really was.
That's it! It's The Alien Factor! Thanks everyone.

My thoughts as I was watching **Syzygy** - Apparently the episode was named when a cat jumped up on the keyboard. * I grew up in the part of the country this episode takes place in, and these people don''t sound remotely like they are from that area. Maine and New Hampshire are constantly fighting for first place in the "America's Worst Accent" Olympics. * Van Wilder ends up dead after trying to do a good deed. Scully is pissed about whatever. The otherwise religious Scully ain't buying the religious stuff. Could it be... SATAN? * So... the local high school's satanic goat mascot is just coincidence? #8220;Maybe if we weren #8217;t virgins we wouldn #8217;t be so scared #8221; #8211; you know, I think you #8217;re right. Let me help you with that. **CAN I PLAY NAKED MOVIE STAR GAMES?**

So... "Shipper" means you want them to hook up? Just checking my English- gt;Jargon translation.

There has been a fair amount of critiquing, if not complaining, earlier on (valid or not, I'm not judging), but as someone who falls squarely into the demo for the podcast, I love it. More than anything, I love that Kumail and his guests are full willing to point out some of the stupid and goofy shit that happens in each episode, while really respecting the show. That really makes the podcast for me. I have tried to listen to a podcast involving another old show (a pretty good show, in fact, but will remain nameless so I don't "out" the podcast), but damn, the hosts were so fanboyish and serious in their fan-love for the show they were talking about, they completely overlooked some of the ridiculousness and raved about the "brilliant" plot and were just so earnest about the whole effort that I couldn't handle it. Meanwhile I'm seeing all of the nutty things that make no sense in each episode, but were never commented on. You can still be a fan and make fun of the stuff in the show that doesn't make sense or might be unintentionally funny. Also, I love the banter, and c'mon, we've all seen the episode at least once, or we wouldn't be listening (and if you didn't watch an episode, why are you listening) so we don't need a detailed rundown of plot points from start to finish. Something that I've always hated in other tv show podcasts, and I'm grateful that Kumail and co. skips them or just does a basic treatment, and brings up details as necessary as the conversation goes forward. If you are talking to some of your friends about an episode of a show you've seen, do you run down the plot points and storyline? No. You talk about the stuff you liked, the stuff you thought was awesome, the stuff you hated, and other shows and other random things that the episode reminded you of. Since I obviously land right in the bullseye of the target demo and Kumail's sense of humor is right up my alley, I can't really offer much in the way of critique except to remind Kumail - this is your thing, man, don't let the whiners put pressure on you to change things up unless it actually makes sense to do so. I love it as is. Unlike all the other podcasts out there, it's like hanging out listening to friends talk about a show you like, and that's all I really want. Keep it up!

WRITING.TEXT: Despite cringing furiously at the idea of Melrose Place, I hit play on episode 2, and have listened to about half so far. I could totally listen along with a show with you guys. BUT I don't think I can bring myself to actually watch Melrose Place. But later on, different show, yeah, I could see that. Melrose Place... that's a bit of a tough sell. I don't really have any criticisms, every podcast does things differently. Maybe your intro sounded a bit contrived, like you were reading but trying to sound like you were just talking, and almost pulled it off, just came up a bit short. And the JRE riff at the start should probably be changed, it's just too much. So, I'm sold on the idea of you guys doing a podcast and your style, I'd listen. But.. Melrose Place... I don't know if I can get over that.

**Piper Maru** - What a great episode! Seeing the soldier actually lift the gate to let Scully through seemed strange, like it was just a giant prop (probably was). I don't think I've ever seen a gate that wasn't automatic. Mulder, don't touch the slimy Frenchman! Don't... oh, too late. Am I the only one that thought it was strange that the Frenchman's wife ran away from him about 30 seconds after him acting creepy? In reality, isn't that a little strange, unless he had a history of smacking her around? Wow, Geraldine has an old school musket under the desk! (Oh, guess that's with a "J") Hmm. Mulder flying to Hong Kong on Skinner's dime. Again. Damn that pesky Mulder! Oh, uzis! So 20th century cocaine cowboy! Skinner picked the wrong TGI Friday's today.

WRITING.TEXT: Court ranks, bushi alliances, and calendar would probably take some work, but it will go on the list. I think in Ep116-117, the point is that the "name" is preserved and bestowed like a corporation. People would be adopted in to the "family" to preserve the name, which carries all the political/social cachet (rank/privilege/or historical value), and people adopted in would either be doing it on behalf of their own clan and/or to be given headship of their own clan if they were not the first son, or maybe even as a simple social boost conferred on them to get a better "name". There were a lot of reasons. For example Mori Motoharu and Takakage were adopted in to other clans to take them over on behalf of the Mori, but also to install them as heads of their own clans. They were no longer part of "Mori Inc.", but they were a benefit as allies, and as younger sons, also gained position as clan leaders. It was less about the individual name, and more about continuing to extend the "family" name into the future, even if the majority of members after a certain point were not even related to the founders. In the case of Motoharu and Takakage, they gave up the Mori name, but in order to benefit it. Not sure if that directly addresses the question... And, yeah, 2016 should see us with some pretty good interviews.

WRITING.TEXT: This is pretty much all fiction. The Samurai were a social class you were pretty much born into by the Edo period. You couldn't just "become" a Samurai. Prior to the Edo period, it was more fluid. Hideyoshi stopped social mobility, making it a much more strict social order. You were a Samurai or you weren't at that point. It wasn't so much that he gave dirt grubbing peasants the option of staying a farmer or becoming a Samurai, but it was mostly to tell the country Samurai, "either you stick to the land and give up your swords, or you fall under a Daimyo" - it was his way of taking the power out of the countryside and getting it under his government. All the notions of honor and fidelity and killing yourself when your lord dies is mostly BS. You might want to check out the Samurai Archives podcast, there are a few episodes that tackle these myths and misconceptions.

The Samurai Archives Japanese History Podcast
WRITING.TEXT: Hi everyone! I didn't see any Japanese history podcasts anywhere here, so I'm tossing out ours. We cover Japanese history from stone age Japan to generally the end of the 19th century, although we've touched on WWII, and our (obvious) focus is the history of the Samurai. It's basically the podcast for samurai-archives.com. Our episodes are quite rangy, we go from straight up academic discourse on historical events, to breaking out the whiskey and debating historical douchebaggery of Samurai warlords. We also try to mix in other disciplines, including philosophy and psychology, and do interviews as well. We've had on armor experts, martial artists, academics, other history podcasters, and have covered academic conferences. We keep Japanese history as a base, but get quite broad, so there is usually something for everyone. Questions, comments, and so on are welcome. Itunes: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/samurai-archives-japanese/id430277324?mt=2 *Most recent 115 episodes* Website: http://samuraipodcast.com/ *All episodes* Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/samuraiarchives Reddit: r/samuraipodcast/ Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Samurai-Archives-104533213984/

Well, every Japanese citizen has a family register that lists parents, etc. Everything is pretty well documented. Unfortunately I don't personally know how you get your hands on it. I'd assume you'd have to start at the local city hall.

[History] **[Samurai Archives Japanese History Podcast - Seppuku: Samurai Suicide](http://samuraipodcast.com/seppuku-samurai-suicide-tales-of-the-samurai-1)** NSFW Go deep into the history of Samurai suicide: Seppuku, from it's legendary origins to the modern day, and the stories of the Samurai involved. We cover all aspects of Seppuku, from the proper methods, the ceremony, the types of cuts, as well as the physical and medical implications of cutting your stomach, and the psychology of suicide and modern suicide theory as a way to understand the Samurai mindset. [Website](http://samuraipodcast.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/samuraiarchives) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/SamuraiArchives/) | [Patreon](https://www.patreon.com/samuraiarchives)

[History] **[The Revenge of the 47 Ronin - Samurai Archives Podcast](http://samuraipodcast.com/the-revenge-of-the-47-ronin)** *NSFW* |[itunes](https://itunes.apple.com/podcast/id430277324?mt=2 amp;ls=1) | [stitcher](https://www.stitcher.com/podcast/the-samurai-archives-japanese-history-podcast/samurai-archives-japanese-history-podcast) | [RSS](http://www.samuraipodcast.com/rss)| Everyone knows the tale of the 47 Ronin, right? A stalwart band of righteous Bushido-inspired Samurai take revenge against a greedy and corrupt government official on behalf of their dead lord. That's the story. But what REALLY happened? What's the real story? Was Kira Yoshinaka a despicable and corrupt villain, or were the 47 Ronin 47 thugs dispensing street justice on an innocent old man in the 18th century version of a feudal drive-by? |[Website](http://www.samuraipodcast.com)|[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/SamuraiArchives/)|[Twitter](https://twitter.com/samuraiarchives)|

WRITING.TITLE: Episode Discussion: S07 E21 "Je Souhaite"
WRITING.TEXT: I wasn't sure how to get this started, so I'm just going to get this started. Episode 21 of season 7 is next up on my list, so I'm watching it later today. Then I guess I'll comment on it. If anyone else wants to join me, go for it, and feel free to post here at will.

First off, the fact that I have to watch the X-Files on Hulu instead of Netflix sucks, because I had never intended to actually ever get a subscription to Hulu. But that #8217;s my only option at this point. So far season seven seems to be extremely uneven; terrible episodes mixed with great episodes mixed with quirky one-offs. My running commentary as I watch: Right from the start the music is telling me this is going to be one of those #8220;quirky #8221; episodes: #8220;The Mystery of the Mouth Stealer #8221;! Hey! Will Sasso! Wait #8230; Am I to believe that Anson found a genie wrapped up in a magic carpet in a storage unit? Who wrote this? What sort of Sherlock Holmes magic caused Mulder to realize there was a Genie granting wishes? Giant plot hole. Predicable ending, I saw Mulder #8217;s third wish a mile away. All in all, a typical quirk episode. Not great, not terrible. Better than the worst episodes of the season, but not as good as, say #8220;Brand X (with Jigsaw) #8221; or #8220;Fight Club #8221;. That being said, the fact that Mulder just sort of pulls the idea of a Genie straight out of the depths of his ass truly boggles my mind. Worst writing ever.
Yeah.... no.
I liked the comedic aspects, but the writing is *terrible*.
What about Mulder closing his eyes, throwing a dart, and landing on "Genie!"?
Am I correct in understanding Vince Gilligan wrote this one? Pretty disappointing writing for the guy that came up with Breaking Bad.

Based on some google gymnastics it looks like this is probably from Picket Fences. I'm not sure of the episode number, but this article talks about this episode specifically: http://www.nytimes.com/1993/10/22/arts/tv-weekend-a-vigilante-mayor-for-rome-wis.html Looks like it aired in 1993.

WRITING.TITLE: Samurai Archives Japanese History Podcast: The Revenge of the 47 Ronin - Tales of the Samurai #2

WRITING.TEXT: "Ninja Black Costumes" are not real. They were made up for Kabuki plays based on the dark costumes Bunraku puppeteers wore to hide from the audience. It sounds like you are basing your question on Shogun: Total War.

If you cut a line from north to south, Ieyasu is from the east, and Mitsunari is from the west of that line. In Japanese they don't use North and South, they use East and West. "North" would refer to Ezo/Hokkaido.

WRITING.TITLE: Do antidepressants cause any permanent changes in the brain that persist even after stopping them?
WRITING.TEXT: Just curious if we know if/what changes may be permanent. Obviously there are short term changes, or changes that take place while a person is actively taking antidepressants, but is there any evidence of changes beneficial, toxic, or otherwise from long term use that persist even after you stop? Examples could be personality changes, enlargement or shrinking of brain structures, neurogenesis or neurotoxicity, whatever. My understanding is that there are probably beneficial changes that come from relieving the physical stress on the brain caused by depression - anything else?

WRITING.TEXT: Somehow I totally missed this, and it's probably too late, but as far as podcast episodes go, I'd recommend the following for inspiration: Episodes 120-121: A pretty complete rundown of life in an Edo-period village http://samuraipodcast.com/peasant-life-during-the-edo-period http://samuraipodcast.com/ep121-peasant-life-during-the-edo-period-p2 Episode 135: Seppuku and Samurai suicide http://samuraipodcast.com/seppuku-samurai-suicide-tales-of-the-samurai-1 Episode 138: The 47 Ronin http://samuraipodcast.com/the-revenge-of-the-47-ronin Episode 105: Samurai succession and inheritance http://samuraipodcast.com/ep105-sengoku-samurai-inheritance-and-succession-bonus-episode-8 Episodes 59-60: Edo period politics http://samuraipodcast.com/ep59-politics-of-the-edo-period-p1 http://samuraipodcast.com/ep60-politics-of-the-edo-period-p2 Not sure how much of that would transfer over to a D amp;D game, but maybe you'll find something useful there. There's probably other episodes, but that's what comes immediately to mind for some of the nuts and bolts of the Edo period.

WRITING.TITLE: [TOMT] [Movie] Two fully armored Samurai fight one-on-one combat
WRITING.TEXT: I'm trying to figure out which Samurai film has two samurai warriors in full armor engage in one on one combat on the field of battle in front of both armies, and one grapples the other to the ground and kills him with a knife. I believe the context was that one calls out the other, so rather than the two armies battling, the two Samurai fight each other in front of the armies. It was a color movie, pre-2000, possibly Akira Kurosawa, but I'm not sure. And if a Youtube link exists, that would be great too.

This is nonsense. During the Heian period, Samurai would call out samurai, but by the 16th century mass formations of army and cavalry would clash on the battlefield. Whoever came up with that stereotype is an idiot.

The reason for this is because they have absolutely no idea what they're talking about. By the 16th century, Japan was fielding armies as large or larger than any country in Europe at the time. Battle strategy was absolutely essential to survival for a Sengoku Daimyo. Calling out other samurai to fight one on one was a thing of the distant past by then. In the entire 16th century there's only a couple examples, and they are notable because it never happened. By 1600, the lead up to the battle of Sekigahara involved 200,000 men engaged in battle and castle sieges across the country, with the decisive battle taking place in October of 1600, with probably over 25,000 dead. It's all nonsensical gibberish.
Solved! That's it, thanks!

It's a lever. It multiplies force. https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Wikijunior:How_Things_Work/Lever More effective than what? You have two hands, there are no other biological ways to grip a weapon other than one handed, which is less effective than two for obvious reasons. Odd question.
What does a modern Samurai eat for lunch?
He served Nobunaga for like 8 months and then faded into obscurity. I mean, it's cool, but...

WRITING.TEXT: Most exciting to least exciting: 1. Running around the library finding books that fit my needs (Yay! I'm on fire! I'm fulfilling my purpose in life!) 2. Flipping through them to find the pages I need (Thrilling! Hyperfocused!) 3. Photocopying and collecting together the info (Fun! I'm in the zone!) 4. Organizing the copies into order of usefulness (Interesting! I'm getting the info I need!) 5. Reading through the info (Ok, I guess! But I have other things I could be doing right now.) 6. Taking Notes (I'm hungry. I need to check my email. I wonder what's on Netflix?) 7. Writing an outline (I still need to finish Gears of War 4. I really want to start reading that book by Dr. Theodore Millon that I started yesterday. My skin is on fire!) 8. Writing the paper (OMG I'm in pain! It burns! It burns!)

WRITING.TITLE: EP159 Interview with Sengoku Daimyo's Chronicles of Japan Podcast host Joshua Badgley

WRITING.TEXT: Going *deep* with the cawlmedy references my mans!
gt; Even with this information I recognize that samurai are by far the more disciplined of the two. Where did you get this nonsense? WTF.
http://samurai-archives.com/title.html

This is not historically accurate. "Ninja" weren't a separate class of trained martial artist assassins in black pajamas. They weren't even known as ninja, they were "Shinobi", which were simply another word for spies. There was no such thing as an assassin clan of ninja that farmed out their services. That's just not historically accurate at all. There was no mountain clan of assassin spies who offered services, but just Samurai who would infiltrate other clan's lands as a spy. This whole black pajama wearing assassin clan ninja thing was a fiction that came later, and really isn't even connected to the Shiniobi, except as an inspiration. This is a huge misconception, unfortunately no one chooses to actually read a book.

WRITING.TITLE: The Origin of the One-Eyed Dragon: Date Masamune (Part 1) - Tales of the Samurai #8

WRITING.TEXT: It's called Genpuku. The "ritual" has nothing to do with the duel. It just means that he takes an adult name and hairstyle, like a Bar Mitzvah. Around this time some sons of Samurai would sit in on a battle as their "first battle" from a safe position, although rarely some actually participated (like Chosokabe Motochika).

WRITING.TITLE: Why do dogs have such extreme diversity in size, shape, and attributes when compared to cats?
WRITING.TEXT: Domestic dogs have an extreme amount of variety when compared to domestic cats. Why?
gt;They dont. The biggest cat is twice the size of the biggest dog. It's been a while since I've seen a 400 pound domestic housecat.
Chihuahuas and St. Bernards weren't independently domesticated from large and small canines, they come from the same source. Domesticated cats lack the diversity of domesticated dogs.

Do a DNA test through 23andMe and [Ancestry.com](https://Ancestry.com). You'll get matched with hundreds or thousands of relatives, and also have your mother do one, it will tell you which relatives are related to you via your father that way. Then start contacting your closest relatives on your father's side. You'll find it eventually. I have over 2000 relatives showing, and about 10 people who are second cousins or closer. People who do these tests are usually interested in genealogy, and will be able to help you out. I'd say get this in process while you do the rest of the stuff.
You should apply to be an expert here, we need more qualified people who can post quality answers.

The reason that Tsunetomo wrote the entire book was because he was let go by the new lord of the clan he worked for when the new lord became of age (the lord found Tsunetomo to be a hard-headed and obnoxious old man with a hard-on for the good old days of yore, and his contemporaries agreed) so Tsunetomo wrote the book which amounts to a "You yung'uns get off my lawn!". He was a bitter old man angry because law forbid him to kill himself when his old lord died, and who hated the "modern" times that he lived in, and wanted a return to the time of wars that he never experienced. That's the historical facts, but everyone \*not\* in Japan has romanticized and blown his mostly forgotten book out of proportion. His book was long dead and forgotten until Imperial Japan resurrected it before WWII. It should all be taken with a mountain of salt. Side Note: Bushido was invented during the Edo period, long after the wars were over to justify the existence of a mostly useless warrior class in peaceful times.
More like wildeb-b-b-beest.

He was a former slave who Nobunaga, who was always fascinated with foreign things/objects, gave a ceremonial position to for a few months before he (Nobunaga) died, and then Yasuke was lost to history. That's really all there is to it. Anything that says much more than that is just pure speculation.

No, knowledge isn't passed on genetically. One could theorize that there would be side effects that would benefit future offspring: educated children will theoretically prefer educated spouses over uneducated ones, so over a number of generations if "intelligent" people are hooking up, the offspring would in theory benefit from the genetic components of intelligence that are passed on (since you need at least a little extra intelligence to get an advanced education). Also education raises socioeconomic status, so offspring would gain from those benefits, like not going to terrible schools, probably not living in a place with lead based paint to eat, better food, less environmental stress, less mental health problems. The sum total of this benefit over generations would probably at least prevent cognitive declines.

WRITING.TITLE: Do the memories of people with anterograde amnesia degrade over time?
WRITING.TEXT: People with anterograde amnesia are unable to create **new** memories, so apparently every time they wake up, it's the same day over and over again (essentially). So the last thing they would remember would be the final memories before being afflicted with anterograde amnesia. Do those final memories "age"? As time goes on, do those memories feel more distant? Or does it always feel like they just happened?

WRITING.TITLE: Does the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle describe a literal or figurative effect?
WRITING.TEXT: At the most basic level, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle is usually described as observing something changes it. Is this literal, as in the instrument you use to observe it bumps it and changes its velocity/location etc? Or is this a more woo woo particle physics effect where something resolves or happens by the simple act of observation? If you blindfold a person next to a pool table, give them a pool cue, and have them locate the balls on the table with the cue (with the balls moving or not), they will locate them by hitting them, but in the act of "observing" (hitting them), their location is then changed. Is this a representative example of the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle? There is a lot of weirdness and woo woo around how people understand what the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle actually is, so a basic and descriptive science answer would be great.
So how did the woo woo magical thinking about it become so mainstream?
Most responsible adults "quarantine" newborns for extended periods as a matter of course. The human immune system isn't so fragile that some time away from others will have any negative consequences.

WRITING.TEXT: It seems, structurally speaking, that putting a water pipe next to a wind pipe is just asking for disaster - suck water or food down the wrong tube, and you could die. Why are both of these pipes right next to each other? Is there a benefit?

During the Sengoku period, the Samurai-Daimyo relationship was *very* quid pro quo. The vassals followed as long as the Daimyo provided. And in most cases "provided" meant land. Daimyo fought constantly during the Sengoku for land for their vassals, not so much because they were trying to "take over the map". Takeda Shingen kept going North into Shinano not just to have epic battles with Uesugi Kenshin, but for land and sea access for his vassals. They needed land, and they needed salt, and if he couldn't provide, they'd get rid of him, just like he did with his own father. The whole Bushido concept of a Samurai would die for his lord or do anything for his lord is all Edo period invention. If the guy above you doesn't provide, you don't do what he says. And in a lot of cases that meant that the lord would find himself on the wrong side of a sharp blade.
I don't really think video games or anime have much place here.

I would really hesitate to use "Bushido" as a flair, I cringe at what that could bring. It's probably the most misunderstood aspect of Japanese history. Something more generic like "Philosophy" would probably be a little better. I'm sure there's a sub somewhere dedicated to Bushido exclusively.
There are probably no less than 5 episodes dedicated to this here, and probably more: http://samuraipodcast.com/

I'm only advocating for *only* discussion of historical aspects, not for "banning" anything. Proactively encouraging video games and anime can backfire, considering most people rarely read the rules and rarely consider what they are posting. I have spent the past 4 years deleting the most random video game, anime, and martial arts nonsense you could imagine. My pie in the sky dream would be for this sub to be exclusively about *history* in whatever context, but again, the volume of weird random tangentially related stuff like Samurai T-shirts and electronic Euromusic from youtube layed over an image of a temple, or pictures of ahistorical robo-demons in Japanese armor has been overwhelming. I'm mainly looking to trim out that stuff and leave all of the history, in whatever form. If you scroll through the history of this sub, you'll see it's awful light on straight up history discussion.

It was created during the Edo period, after the wars were long finished, to give the bloated bureaucratic class who happened to carry swords a sense of purpose. Most importantly there is no formulated set of rules, it was a general philosophy that wasn't really established as much of anything until the Meiji period, and in particular after that in the 1930s.
It wasn't called Bushido in the early Edo period, and Tokugawa Ieyasu didn't have a direct hand in it at all.

WRITING.TITLE: Japanese History Discord Server

WRITING.TEXT: We have had a Samurai/Japanese History Discord server for well over a year, but I didn't think to post it. So here you go. It gets a lot of traffic, and has some good stuff.

WRITING.TITLE: Samurai-Archives.com - The End of an Era
WRITING.TEXT: I wanted to make an official post since this subreddit is partially run by staff from the Samurai Archives. This might only be interesting to a handful of people here, but the hosting company for the Samurai Archives website and Wiki is shutting down in December, so after about 21 years on the internet, I have decided to discontinue the website. The main site hasn't been updated in about 13 years, and still mostly contains HTML dating back to 1999, so I don't really see a point in finding a new host and shelling out a yearly fee for what has really become just an online archive for a very old website. Unfortunately the [Samurai Archives Japanese History Wiki](https://wiki.samurai-archives.com/) will also go down with the ship. The wiki went up in 2007 and currently has well over 7,000 Japanese history articles. I'm looking at creating a new wiki, although it will have to be done from scratch, so I don't really know what will happen with it. All that being said, the [Podcast](https://www.samuraipodcast.com/) and [Forum](https://www.tapatalk.com/groups/japanese_history/) will still be around. And who knows, maybe eventually a new website will develop. Anyway, thanks to all the supporters over the decades!

A few thousand hits a day, a couple hundred bucks a year. The problem is the Wiki software, it was heavily modded and customized, so moving to a new SQL host would be a difficult task that would require database and coding expertise far beyond myself and my resources. Regardless, I wouldn't be giving anyone anything. Someone could have light administration privileges, but there's no way I'm transferring anything to anyone.
I'm not aware of anything that can "translate" an SQL database into readable files. Maybe someone here would know?
I have the full SQL database backup.

Depending on how sick you are, it could increase [Cognitive Load](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_load) by adding extraneous sensory data, like pain, discomfort, etc. which makes it more difficult to concentrate on the task in front of you. The extra input caused by the illness could use up attentional resources.
